title: Feuding couple criticised for spending more than £500,000 on divorce lawyers
text:
Melanie Panzone (left) and her mother-in-law Anne Read (right) outside London’s Court of Appeal (Pictures: Champion News)

A leading judge has criticised two highly-educated professionals for a ‘destructive and disproportionate’ legal battle over their failed marriage.

In the latest round of Melanie Panzone and Jonathon Read’s legal battle, a high-ranking judge lamented the impact of their lengthy legal fight, which has cost hundreds of thousands of pounds.

At the latest round of their fight, Lady Justice King told the Court of Appeal that the pair’s fights over their children and money had continued for around five years and been ‘destructive and disproportionate’, as well as ‘emotionally bruising’.

The London court heard how the pair spent more than £500,000 on lawyers after their 12-year marriage broke down.

Lady Justice said both were highly educated and had high-earning careers – Mr Read worked in the City when they married in 2002 and Ms Panzone is a solicitor.

City lawyer Melanie Panzone outside the Court of Appeal in London (Picture: Champion News)

But Lady Justice suggested evidence showed that their comfortable lifestyle could not be maintained, largely because of the ‘intolerable burden’ of legal costs.

In a written ruling on the case, she continued: ‘This is yet another case where a highly-educated couple with young children has engaged in lengthy, destructive and disproportionate legal proceedings’.

Mr Read had complained about decisions made by a lower-ranking judge and appeal judges had considered a number of legal issues.

Mum's breast cancer spotted by museum's thermal imaging camera

Appeal judges had ruled in Mr Read’s favour in some aspects.

But he lost a fight over a £150,000 lump sum he had been ordered to pay.

Appeal judges had considered legal issues relating to a flat, worth nearly £300,000, in Rio Mar, Panama.

They said Mr Read had bought the flat when the pair were married.

But, they added that legal ownership of the flat was vested in a company and the only shareholder of that company was Mr Read’s mother, Anne Read.

Jonathan Read’s mother Anne (Picture: Champion News)

A lower-ranking judge had ruled that Mr Read was the ‘sole beneficial owner’ of the flat.

Mrs Read had appealed, with the support of Mr Read, suggesting the lump sum order should be ‘set aside’.

Appeal judges said there had been a ‘procedural irregularity’ in the way the lower-ranking judge handled the case and indicated that Mrs Read was the ‘legal’ owner of the flat.

But they said the flat was a ‘financial resource’ which Mr Read had or was likely to have.

Lady Justice King added: “The lump sum order in favour of the wife remains and it is now a matter for the husband whether he requires the legal owner, his mother Mrs Read, to sell the property in order to raise the money with which to satisfy the order, or whether he chooses to raise it in some other way.’

description: Melanie Panzone and Jonathon Read criticised in Court of Appeal during latest stage of their £500,000 legal battle over divorce.
